definition:
The binomial coefficients $$\begin{aligned}
    {n\choose r} = \frac{n!}{(n\!-\!r)!r!},\end{aligned}$$ where $n$ is
a non-negative integer and $r \in \{0,\,1,\,2,\,\ldots,\,n\}$, can be
generalized for all integer and non-integer values of $n$ by using the
form $$\begin{aligned}
    {n\choose r} = \frac{n(n\!-\!1)(n\!-\!2)\ldots(n\!-\!r\!+\!1)}{r!}; \end{aligned}$$
here $r$ may be any non-negative integer. Then gets the form
$$\begin{aligned}
    (1\!+\!z)^{\alpha} = \sum_{r = 0}^{\infty}{\alpha\choose r}z^r 
 = 1\!+\!{\alpha\choose1}z\!+\!{\alpha\choose 2}z^2\!+\cdots\end{aligned}$$
It is not hard to show that the radius of convergence of this series is
1. This series expansion is valid for every complex number $\alpha$ when
$|z| < 1$, and it presents such a of the $(1\!+\!z)^{\alpha}$ which gets
the value 1 in the point $z = 0$.

In the case that $\alpha$ is a non-negative integer and $r$ is great
enough, one factor in the numerator of $$\begin{aligned}
{\alpha\choose r} = 
  \frac{\alpha(\alpha\!-\!1)(\alpha\!-\!2)\ldots(\alpha\!-\!r\!+\!1)}{r!} \end{aligned}$$
vanishes, and hence the corresponding binomial coefficient
${\alpha\choose r}$ equals to zero; accordingly also all following
binomial coefficients with a greater $r$ are equal to zero. It means
that the series is left to being a finite sum, which gives the binomial
theorem.

For all complex values of $\alpha$, $\beta$ and non-negative integer
values of $r$, $s$, the [*Pascal’s formula*]{} $$\begin{aligned}
  {\alpha\choose r}\!+\!{\alpha\choose r\!+\!1} = {{\alpha\!+\!1}\choose{r\!+\!1}}\end{aligned}$$
and [*Vandermonde’s convolution*]{} $$\begin{aligned}
 \sum_{r = 0}^s{\alpha\choose r}\!{\beta\choose{s\!-\!r}} = {{\alpha\!+\!\beta}\choose s}\end{aligned}$$
hold (the latter is proved by expanding the power
$(1\!+\!z)^{\alpha+\beta}$ to series). Cf. Pascal’s rule and Vandermonde
identity.
